measured_by: three-item permissibility scale (comfort, appropriateness, forbidden reversed)
justification: "Participants then rated the following items… 1. I would be comfortable if this fund manager invested… 2. It is appropriate… 3. This fund manager should be forbidden… (reversed). We computed the mean (α = .83), which served as our dependent variable."

measured_by: five-item hypocrisy scale (e.g., ‘This fund manager is two-faced’)
justification: "Participants also rated the moral hypocrisy of the fund manager using a five-item scale (e.g., 'This fund manager is two-faced', α = .94; Effron & Miller, 2015)."

"…we checked whether people generally judge investing in short positions less favorably than long positions (3 items, e.g., 'buying long/short derivatives is moral/immoral', αlong = .98, αshort = .98)."
construct: moral acceptability of trade / judgment of long/short derivatives

measured_by: two-item trader evaluation scale (good/bad people; wish good/bad things)
justification: "…generally judge traders who make short (vs. long) investments less favorably (2 items, e.g., 'people that buy long/short derivatives are good/bad people', αlong = .89, αshort = .83)."

measured_by: two-item self-interest scale (attractive/unattractive; likely/unlikely to trade)
justification: "…and are less willing to personally adopt a short than long position (2 items, 'buying long/short derivatives is very attractive/very unattractive to you', αlong = .94, αshort = .94)."
"We also measured political orientation from 1 (liberal) to 7 (conservative)."

measured_by: six-item financial literacy quiz (e.g., highest return asset; risk of diversification)
justification: Supplementary materials list six specific financial-literacy questions that "were originally used in Agnew & Szykman (2005)" and constitute the objective investment knowledge test.
